facts: Ambulances are designed like moving mini-hospitals, carrying medical tools and supplies so paramedics can start treatment on the way to a hospital.
Fire engines have powerful pumps and long hoses that can move large amounts of water quickly, even from hydrants that are far from the fire.
Police cars often include radios and computers so officers can get updates and share information with other responders in real time.
Many emergency vehicles use special flashing lights and sirens because bright colors and changing sounds help people notice them faster in traffic.
In some places, motorcycles and bicycles are used for emergency response because they can travel through crowded streets more easily than larger vehicles.
Helicopters and airplanes can serve as emergency vehicles by flying patients, organs for transplant, or rescue teams to places that are hard to reach by road.
Emergency vehicles are usually inspected and maintained more often than regular vehicles because they must work reliably during urgent situations.
sources_hint: For more details, check official transportation safety resources, emergency service agency websites, and vehicle design references used by EMS, fire, and police departments.
